newsitem.title: FRANCE: Eurotunnel continues talks with creditor banks.
newsitem.headline: Eurotunnel continues talks with creditor banks.

text.p: Troubled Channel Tunnel operator Eurotunnel kept up intensive talks with its bankers on Tuesday in a desperate bid to keep going.

The co-chairmen of the Anglo-French company, Alistair Morton and Patrick Ponsolle, were negotiating with six banks to break a logjam on debt refinancing after a mandate expired on Monday for court-appointed mediators who have been helping in the talks.
Eurotunnel has been seeking to rejig around 70 billion francs ($14 billion) of debt and unpaid interest owed to its syndicate of 225 banks since it froze payments last year.

"The negotiations are continuing," a Eurotunnel spokeswoman told Reuters. "It's very, very hard and every millimetre counts. It's rather like "Mission: Impossible'," she said, referring to the cult action film and TV series.

The stakes in the negotiations were raised by Eurotunnel in February when it asked the president of the Paris commercial court, Jean-Pierre Mattei, to name Jean-Pierre Badinter and Lord Wakeham as mediators.

That move infuriated the banks, which saw it as the first legal step that could lead to a loss of control and a court-driven solution, with the implicit threat of an insolvency ruling by the court president if they did not accept.

The court president has the discretion to allow the negotiations to continue if it appeared there were hopes of an agreement. "He could allow a period of a few hours or a few days," the spokeswoman said.
But overhanging the talks was the insolvency option, if the two sides were unable to strike an accord.

Lawyer Georges Berlioz, adviser to the Adacte Eurotunnel shareholder group, said there were three possibilities -- a debt agreement, no agreement and an insolvency process, or no agreement but the court allows more time for talks.
Although no one wanted insolvency, the consequences were more serious for banks than the shareholders, he said.

Shareholders, at least 600,000 of them in France, have seen at least two-thirds of their investment drain away since they invested in the 1987 flotation at 35 francs per share. The company also issued new shares in 1994 at 24 francs.
Banks have received millions in fees and interest payments.

Under French insolvency rules, the aim is to protect the company as a going concern, with up to 18 months of protection from creditors with a view to a long-term restructuring. Eurotunnel breaks even at the operating level, before its debt service burden, and could continue functioning.
Meanwhile, Eurotunnel's share are suspended until the outcome of the talks. The shares closed on Friday at 9.20 francs per share in Paris and 113.5 pence in London.
